results.description:
Overview

Cosmo Police Galivan stars a futuristic cop somewhat inspired by RoboCop. It is based on the tokusatsu show Space Sheriff Gavan, which has a number of different aliases depending on the localization.

The first game is a Famicom platformer with open-world elements that allows the player to explore their surroundings for upgrades and secrets. The second game is a straightforward side-scrolling brawler with multiple protagonists.
results.name: Cosmo Police Galivan

results.description:
Overview

The Pro Mahjong Kiwame series focuses on high-level mahjong play. There have been multiple versions released on many consoles after the initial Super Famicom/Arcade entry. An abbreviated list includes:

  • Pro Mahjong Kiwame I, II and III for the Super Famicom.
  • Pro Mahjong Kiwame GB and GB 2 for the Nintendo Game Boy and Game Boy Color.
  • Pro Mahjong Kiwame S for the Sega Saturn.
  • Pro Mahjong Kiwame D for the Sega Dreamcast.
  • Pro Mahjong Kiwame 64 for the N64.
  • Pro Mahjong Kiwame Plus and Plus 2 for the Sony PlayStation.
results.name: Pro Mahjong Kiwame

results.description:
Overview

The Pixel Puzzles franchise is a series of classic style jigsaw puzzle games. Each game in the series has a different theme to it.
results.name: Pixel Puzzles

results.description:
Overview

The Minelvaton Saga are three games set in Minelvaton, with each connecting to the other two games through the persistent world. The same towns, dungeons and other important areas can be visited in each of the three games, often changing with the passage of time.

The games include:

  • Minelvaton Saga: Ragon no Fukkatsu (Famicom, 1987)
  • Silva Saga (Famicom, 1992)
  • Silva Saga II: The Legend of Light and Darkness (Super Famicom, 1993)
results.name: Minelvaton Saga

results.description:
Overview

Copya System's Air Diver series allows the player to enter dogfights with a number of fighter jets. The first game displayed the action from the cockpit, while the sequels used a third-person view that took advantage of the Super Nintendo's Mode 7 capabilities.

It includes: 1990's Air Diver, 1993's Super Air Diver (known as Lock On in the US) and 1995's Super Air Diver 2. The third game is Japan exclusive.
results.name: Air Diver

results.description:
Overview

The Reversion franchise is a series of point and click adventure games that were developed by 3f Interactive.
results.name: Reversion

results.description:
Overview

The Power League games are a series of baseball sims released predominantly on the PC Engine and Super Famicom. They are usually developed and published by Hudson Soft, though often the development duties were passed onto Nowpro.

The series includes: Power League (a.k.a. World Class Baseball), Power League 2-5 and Power League '93 for the PC Engine. Super Power League 1-4 are the four Super Famicom games. There is also Power League 64 for the N64 and Super Power League FX for the PC-FX.
results.name: Power League

results.description:
Overview

Sword World RPG is a fantasy table-top game that offers the same degree of freedom and customization as Dungeons and Dragons, and other RPGs in that vein. The first three games attempted to recreate the open-endedness element of Sword World. The 2009 DS game based on the 2008 "2.0" relaunch of Sword World is more of a visual novel set in the same universe.

The Record of Lodoss War, also created by Group SNE, is set in the same universe. The Lodoss Island, where the Record of Lodoss War novels/games are set, is part of the larger world of Forcelia that is the setting for Sword World.

Sword World has parallels with Germany's Das Schwarze Auge (The Dark Eye) series. Both are table-top games with huge followings in their respective native countries, both are loosely based on Dungeons and Dragons and both have many video game adaptations, including RPGs and adventure games.

Games

TitleSystemRelease Date
Sword World PCNEC PC-980111/27/1992
Sword World SFCSuper Famicom (SNES)8/6/1993
Sword World SFC 2Super Famicom (SNES)7/15/1993
Sword World 2.0Nintendo DS10/29/2009
results.name: Sword World

results.description:
Overview

The Thoroughbred Breeder series focuses on raising horses for the purposes of racing, ensuring the right food and exercise is given to them and keeping track of their health and athletic ability. The games usually feature a mode where the player can watch horse races and bet on them for additional funds.

Games

TitleSystemRelease Date
Thoroughbred BreederSuper Famicom (SNES)08/27/1993
Thoroughbred Breeder IISuper Famicom (SNES)06/08/1994
Thoroughbred Breeder II PlusPlayStation11/17/1995
Thoroughbred Breeder IIISuper Famicom (SNES)10/18/1996
Thoroughbred Breeder: Sekai Seiha-henPlayStation04/23/1998
results.name: Thoroughbred Breeder

results.description:
Overview

The Arcade Archives are a series of classic arcade games that have been ported to the PlayStation 4 and Switch, by Hamster. Switch's games also include those of Nintendo arcade games.

Games in the Arcade Archives series have launched at a price point of 823 yen, or approximately eight American dollars, for each game.

A spin-off of the Arcade Archives series is ACA NeoGeo, which releases not only on PlayStation 4, but Xbox One, Switch, and Windows 10 as well.
results.name: Arcade Archives

results.description:
Overview

Shin Nippon Pro Wrestling was founded in 1972 by Antonio Inoki, a former professional wrestler, which then briefly passed to video game developer Yuke's before being sold to its current owners Bushiroad, a Japanese CCG developer. Its roster over the decades has featured many prominent Japanese and American pro wrestlers, including Big Van Vader and Jim Neidhart.

There are two "eras" for Shin Nippon Pro Wrestling video game adaptations. They include:

Varie

Varie put out three Super Famicom games between 1993-1995, one of which was ported to the PC Engine CD by Fujicom. The first of these was Shin Nippon Pro Wrestling: Chou Senshi in Tokyo Dome, the first Shin Nippon Pro Wrestling game.

Yuke's

In 1995, Yuke's picked up the license to produce Shin Nippon Pro Wrestling games, and would later purchase a majority share of the promotion. Yuke's games usually contained the phrase "Toukon Retsuden" or "Toukon Road" in their titles. The first Shin Nippon Pro Wrestling Toukon Retsuden game was published on the PlayStation, but the series would also see releases for the N64, Dreamcast, Game Boy Advance and WonderSwan.
results.name: New Japan Pro Wrestling

results.description: Elvira was featured in several games in the mid to late 80's, most notably three horror adventure games by Horrorsoft.
results.name: Elvira's Movie Macabre

results.description:
History

Slingo was originally designed by Sal Falciglia to be a physical slot machine game. However, while pitching his casino machine he realized that heavy hardware was going to be a tough sell and worked with Bob Bielecki and John Driscoll of Shadow Interactive Inc. to produce a digital prototype in 1995. The game was pitched to America Online who bought it in 1996 and launched it as a multiplayer game in which players scores were compared on a leaderboard.

Different versions of Slingo were released later, including the poker-style Slingo Xpress, CD-ROM versions, a handheld from Tiger Electronics, and even a lottery scratcher card.

In 2013 Slingo was purchased by RealNetworks. Slingo continues to run a website with different variations of the game, the most recent of which is Slingo Supreme on iOS.
results.name: Slingo

results.description:
Overview

Soukou Kihei Votoms is a serial sci-fi anime TV series originally shown between 1983 and 1984 on TV Tokyo. It has received multiple computer and video game adaptations since then, all of which were released exclusively in Japan. These games are often mecha-based shoot 'em ups and simulation games, and many are not unlike the MechWarrior series. It also inspired a few table-top games.

The titular Votoms mech has also made several appearances in other games, most notably the crossover series Super Robot Taisen.
results.name: Soukou Kihei Votoms

results.description:
Overview

Solstice and Equinox are a pair of games that feature isometric puzzle-platforming action, a genre that saw its heyday for the Commodore 64 with games like Head Over Heels and Knight Lore. They were developed by defunct UK development studio Software Creations (which briefly became known as Acclaim Studios Manchester).

In Solstice, released for the NES in 1990, the player assumes the role of Shadax the wizard as he fights to rescue the world (and the comely Princess Eleanor) from Morbius the Malevolent, a powerful and invincible rival. In order to beat him, Shadax must first assemble the Staff of Demnos, the parts of which can be found in the dungeons of Kastlerock where the game takes place.

In Equinox, released for the SNES in 1994 (1993 in Japan), the player assumes the role of Glendaal, the son of Shadax. Shadax has been captured by his former apprentice Sonia after she turns evil. Rather than a single dungeon, like in the original game, the player makes their way across the world to eight separate dungeons on eight separate continents. To complicate matters, each dungeon can have numerous entrances and the player must find 12 tokens to summon the boss and defeat them, which opens the way to the next dungeon.

The pair of games are best known for their difficulty and their soundtracks, composed by Tim Follin. Though narratively unrelated to the duo, Software Creations also created Altered Space for the Game Boy which features similar gameplay in a sci-fi setting.
results.name: Solstice

results.description:
Following the success of British BTCC on Swedish Television in the early 90's, the Swedish Touring Car Championship was formed in 1996. In 2010 it was merged with the Danish Touring Car Championship and renamed Scandinavian Touring Car Championship, keeping the STCC acronym and logo.

Video Games

Digital Illusions CE AB developed two STCC games, the first game for Bonnier Multimedia in 1999, and the second for Electronic Arts in 2000.

Since 2008 SimBin Development Team AB have produced STCC - The Game as expansion content for their RACE series.
results.name: STCC

results.description:
Overview

The Mario Discovery Series are five games released on the NES, SNES and PC that feature characters from the Mario universe. The goal of these games is to be educational, providing younger players with knowledge about geography, human history and elementary maths and English.

  • Mario is Missing! is the first and most prominent game in this series. It features Luigi in a starring role as he follows Bowser across the globe in order to find his brother Mario. Most of the game involves solving geography riddles to track Mario down.
  • Mario's Time Machine stars Mario as he attempts to recover artifacts stolen from across history and return them to their correct time periods. The game had both SNES and NES versions with subtle differences.
  • Mario's Early Years are three games meant for a very young audience. Fun with Numbers teaches basic arithmetic, while Fun with Letters teaches the alphabet and basic vocabulary and spelling. Preschool Fun is a mini-game collection.
results.name: Mario Discovery Series

results.description:
Overview

The Super Mahjong series are three games published and possibly developed by I'Max Corp. The first only had a one-on-one mode, but the two sequels allowed for up to four-person games. Though each game had different styles, they did all maintain a fairly comedic tone.
results.name: Super Mahjong

results.description:
Overview

Hakunetsu Pro Yakyuu Ganba League, which roughly means "White Hot Pro Baseball Courage League" ("Ganba" is an exclamation of support, like "courage!" or "go for it!"), are three games that take a leaf from Namco's popular Famista/Family Stadium series to present a semi-serious baseball game with super deformed athletes and an overall cartoonish presentation.

While the second and third game were never released outside of Japan, the first Hakunetsu Pro Yakyuu Ganba League was released in the US as Extra Innings. Like the first RBI Baseball, Extra Innings kept the cartoony visuals of its source game.
results.name: Hakunetsu Pro Yakyuu Ganba League

results.description:
Overview

Dungeon Travelers is a series of fantasy dungeon crawlers inspired by the Wizardry series developed by Aquaplus. While the first title was created as a spin off from the To Heart 2 visual novel, transposing its characters into a traditional fantasy RPG setting, the sequel was focused on new characters created for the game.
results.name: Dungeon Travelers
